item.title: Bangladeshi officials meet student demand to name Nobel laureate as leader
item.dc:creator: Azad Majumder, Karishma Mehrotra, Anant Gupta, Tanbirul Miraj Ripon, Anika Seth
item.description: The selection of Muhammad Yunus by the president, security chiefs and student leaders represents an initial step to restoring order after Sheikh Hasina’s ouster.

item.title: U.S. stock indexes move higher the day after global market rout
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett, Adela Suliman, Michelle Lee, Julian Mark
item.description: Japan’s benchmark Nikkei 225 index ended the day up 10.23 percent on Tuesday, after its biggest single-day point drop Monday.

item.title: Airlines cancel Middle East flights as escalation anxiety rises
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth, Heidi Levine
item.description: Flight cancellations are affecting those trying to return home, as well as those trying to flee.

item.title: Five U.S. troops, 2 contractors injured in rocket attack in Iraq
item.dc:creator: Alex Horton
item.description: U.S. troops at Al Assad air base in Iraq were wounded in a rocket attack carried out by Iranian-back militants, the Pentagon said.

item.title: Most Americans oppose sending U.S. troops to defend Israel, poll finds
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: The findings come as tensions with Hezbollah and a threat from Iran loom over Israel. The United States has repositioned military assets in the region in recent days in preparation to defend Israel.

item.title: Why has the Japanese stock market been on a roller coaster ride?
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee, Julia Mio Inuma
item.description: Record fall one day, record rise the next. The Japanese stock market is gyrating in part because the country’s currency has been weakening — until last month.

item.title: TikTok to remove feature for some users after E.U. says it’s addictive
item.dc:creator: Kyle Melnick
item.description: TikTok Lite is removing a rewards program in E.U. countries after regulators accused the company of creating addictive features that could harm children.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Hasina faces the revenge of history
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: What comes next in Bangladesh is far from certain. The specter of further political violence is real.

item.title: U.N. fires Gaza staff, citing possible involvement in attack on Israel
item.dc:creator: Karen DeYoung
item.description: The U.N. fired nine employees of UNRWA, a key relief agency in Gaza, after determining they “may have been involved” in the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel.

item.title: Houthi drone expert among those killed in U.S. strike in Iraq
item.dc:creator: Alex Horton, Mustafa Salim
item.description: A Houthi commander’s death in Iraq illustrates the cooperation among Iran-backed groups in the Middle East as the region faces the threat of worsening violence.

item.title: Israel on alert for retaliation; U.S. officials say attack may be imminent
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Rachel Pannett, Annabelle Timsit, John Hudson
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu discussed preparations for counterstrikes with his security cabinet. Hamas and Iran blame Israel for the killing of a Hamas leader.

item.title: Mali cuts ties with Ukraine, claiming Kyiv’s involvement in rebel attacks
item.dc:creator: Siobhán O'Grady, Rachel Chason, Serhii Korolchuk
item.description: Kyiv said Mali failed to provide evidence of any Ukrainian involvement in the attacks by Tuareg rebels in northern Mali that killed Russian and Malian troops.

item.title: Maduro perdió las elecciones según actas recopiladas por la oposición
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt, Steven Rich, Ana Herrero, María Luisa Paúl
item.description: Edmundo González habría vencido al presidente Nicolás Maduro el 28 de julio por millones de votos, según muestra un análisis de datos de las actas electorales.

item.title: Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina resigns and flees country
item.dc:creator: Azad Majumder, Rebecca Tan, Karishma Mehrotra, Anant Gupta
item.description: Hasina’s resignation, announced by Gen. Waker-Uz-Zaman, comes after hundreds have been killed in clashes between protesters and security forces in recent weeks.

item.title: How the U.S. military cultivated — and then lost — a key African ally
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chason
item.description: A timeline of key events in the lead-up to the U.S. troop withdrawal on Monday from the West African country of Niger.

item.title: U.S. troops withdraw from strategic West African base as militant threat grows
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chason
item.description: The U.S. military pullout from the sprawling Agadez base in Niger deals a setback to efforts at countering Islamist insurgents and resisting Russian influence.

item.title: Who is Sheikh Hasina, Bangladeshi leader who fled protests?
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Sheikh Hasina resigned as Bangladesh’s prime minister following deadly protests, fleeing to India on Monday.

item.title: Taiwan celebrates Olympic gold (and China tries to ignore it)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Tan, Vic Chiang
item.description: This came after repeated cheers for “Taiwan” — officially “Chinese Taipei” at the Olympics — and an incident in which a sign was snatched at the Paris Games.

item.title: In photos: The scene in Bangladesh after clashes between protesters, security forces
item.dc:creator: Troy Witcher
item.description: Weeks of violence between Bangladeshi security forces and anti-government demonstrators intensified this weekend.

item.title: Thailand may soon take another backward step
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: On Aug. 7, Thailand’s constitutional court may rule to effectively disqualify Pita Limjaroenrat — arguably the country’s most popular politician — from holding office in the near future.

item.title: Maduro lost election, tallies collected by Venezuela’s opposition show
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt, Steven Rich, Ana Herrero, María Luisa Paúl
item.description: Edmundo González likely beat President Nicolás Maduro in the July 28 election by millions of votes, a review of data from election receipts shows.

item.title: First F-16 fighter jets have arrived in Ukraine, Zelensky confirms
item.dc:creator: David Stern
item.description: The planes are unlikely to fly near the front lines, officials said, as there are too few of them — and too many Russian defense systems that can shoot them down.

item.title: Far-right protesters attack hotel housing asylum seekers in violent weekend
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih, Ben Brasch, Adela Suliman, Dan Rosenzweig-Ziff
item.description: Demonstrations in Rotherham, Liverpool, Hull and Bristol turned violent, prompting arrests. Misinformation about a deadly knife attack in Southport, England, spurred far-right protests.
